member.name: F:Robust.Client.GameObjects.GenericVisualizerComponent.Visuals
member.summary:
This is a nested dictionary that maps appearance data keys -> sprite layer keys -> appearance data values -> layer data. While somewhat convoluted, this enables the sprite layer data to be completely modified using only yaml.
In most instances, each of these dictionaries will probably only have a single entry.

member.name: T:Robust.Client.GameObjects.IconComponent
member.summary: This component can be used to give an entity a simple texture which can be used for displaying the entity in some UI elements. The texture must be specified as an RSI state, and will correspond to the first frame of the south-direction. To actually resolve the texture, you can use
member.remarks: This is texture is useful displaying entities that have non-trivial sprites that require some sort of set up in order to display. E.g., entities that randomize their colour by modulating a simple base sprite will look odd if shown directly, and spawning a client-side entity would lead to the colour being randomized each time the UI is updated.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.GameStates.IClientGameStateManager.PartialStateReset(Robust.Shared.GameStates.GameState,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This will perform some setup in order to reset the game to an earlier state. To fully reset the state still needs to be called separately.
member.remarks: This function will delete any networked entities that are not present in the given game state. Any child entities that are in the state will simply be sent to null-space. This will also reset to zero, so that will actually apply the state.
member.param: The state to reset to.

Whether or not to reset for all entities, or only those that have been modified some after the states . This effectively determines whether we should do a full-state reset, or only reset recently modified entities.
Whether to delete all client-side entities (which are never part of the networked game state).

Whether to delete client-side entities that are parented to networked that are about to be deleted during the partial reset. E.g., if this is true, then a client-side muzzle flash effect entity that is parented to a networked gun entity will get deleted if that gun is about to be deleted. If false, the entity will simply be detached to nullspace. This option has no effect if is true.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.Graphics.DrawingHandleBase.Modulate
member.summary: Drawing commands that do NOT receive per-vertex modulation get modulated by this. Specifically, *DrawPrimitives w/ DrawVertexUV2DColor IS NOT AFFECTED BY THIS*. The only code that should ever be setting this is UserInterfaceManager. It's absolutely evil statefulness. I understand it's existence and operation. I understand that removing it would require rewriting all the UI controls everywhere. I still wish it a prolonged death - it's a performance nightmare. - 20kdc

member.name: T:Robust.Client.Graphics.StyleBoxTexture

member.name: T:Robust.Client.Graphics.ShaderInstance
member.summary: A shader instance is a wrapper around a shader that can be used for rendering. It can contain extra, mutable parameters depending on the shader backing it.
member.remarks:
Shader instances are often shared to reduce bloat. As such, they can be made "immutable" to avoid accidentally modifying the shader instance used by every entity on the station.
A shader can be made immutable with . This is irreversible. After doing this, operations such as will throw a .
You can "duplicate" a shader instance to make a separate, once again mutable, copy with .

member.name: P:Robust.Client.Graphics.ShaderInstance.Mutable
member.summary: Whether this shader is mutable. An immutable shader can no longer be edited and is ideal for sharing.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.Graphics.ShaderInstance.MakeImmutable
member.summary: Make this shader permanently immutable.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.Graphics.ShaderInstance.Duplicate
member.summary: Make an identical copy of this shader, that is treated separately for the parameters assigned to it. The copy is also mutable, even if the source is not so.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.Graphics.ShaderPrototype.Instance
member.summary: Retrieves a ready-to-use instance of this shader.
member.remarks: This instance is shared. As such, it is immutable. Use to get a mutable and unique shader instance.

member.remarks: If empty or null, no tooltip is shown in the first place (but OnShowTooltip and OnHideTooltip events are still fired).

member.summary: Overrides the global tooltip delay, showing the tooltip for this control within the specified number of seconds.

member.summary: Should the tooltip track the mouse cursor.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Control.TooltipSupplier
member.summary:
When a tooltip should be shown for this control, this will be invoked to produce a control which will serve as the tooltip (doing nothing if null is returned). This is the generally recommended way to implement custom tooltips for controls, as it takes care of the various edge cases for showing / hiding the tooltip. For an even more customizable approach,
The returned control will be added to PopupRoot, and positioned within the user interface under the current mouse position to avoid going off the edge of the screen. When the tooltip should be hidden, the control will be hidden by removing it from the tree.
It is expected that the returned control remains within PopupRoot. Other classes should not move it around in the tree or move it out of PopupRoot, but may access and modify the control and its children via .
member.remarks: Returning a new instance of a tooltip control every time is usually fine. If for some reason constructing the tooltip control is expensive, it MAY be fine to cache + reuse a single instance but this approach has not yet been tested.

member.name: E:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Control.OnShowTooltip
member.summary:
Invoked when the mouse is hovered over this control for a bit and a tooltip should be shown. Can be used as an alternative to ToolTip or TooltipSupplier to perform custom tooltip logic such as showing a more complex tooltip control.
Any custom tooltip controls should typically be added as a child of UserInterfaceManager.PopupRoot Handlers can use to assist with positioning custom tooltip controls.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Control.SuppliedTooltip
member.summary: If this control is currently showing a tooltip provided via TooltipSupplier, returns that tooltip. Do not move this control within the tree, it should remain in PopupRoot. Also, as it may be hidden (removed from tree) at any time, saving a reference to this is a Bad Idea.

member.summary: Called when this control receives keyboard focus.

member.summary: Called when this control loses keyboard focus (corresponds to UserInterfaceManager.KeyboardFocused).

member.name: M:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Control.ControlFocusExited
member.summary: Fired when a control loses control focus for any reason. See .
member.remarks:
Controls which have some sort of drag / drop behavior should usually implement this method (typically by cancelling the drag drop). Otherwise, if a user clicks down LMB over one control to initiate a drag, then clicks RMB down over a different control while still holding down LMB, the control being dragged will now lose focus and will no longer receive the keyup for the LMB, thus won't cancel the drag. This should also be considered for controls which have any special KeyBindUp behavior - consider what would happen if the control lost focus and never received the KeyBindUp.
There is no corresponding ControlFocusEntered - if a control wants to handle that situation they should simply handle KeyBindDown as that's the only way a control would gain focus.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.IUserInterfaceManager.ControlFocused
member.summary: A control gets "ControlFocused" when a mouse button (or any KeyBinding which has CanFocus = true) is pressed down on the control. While it is focused, it will receive mouse hover events and the corresponding keyup event if it still has focus when that occurs (it will NOT receive the keyup if focus has been taken by another control). Focus is removed when a different control takes focus (such as by pressing a different mouse button down over a different control) or when the keyup event happens. When focus is lost on a control, it always fires Control.ControlFocusExited.

member.name: T:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer
member.summary: A container that lays out its children in a grid. Can define specific count of rows or specific count of columns (not both), and will grow to fill in additional rows/columns within that limit. Alternatively, can define a maximum width or height, and grid will lay out elements (aligned in a grid pattern, not floated) within the defined limit.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.LimitedDimension
member.summary: Indicates whether row or column count has been specified, and thus how items will fill them out as they are added. This is set depending on whether you have specified Columns or Rows.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.UnlimitedDimension
member.summary: Opposite dimension of LimitedDimension

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.LimitType
member.summary: Indicates whether we are limiting based on an explicit number of rows or columns, or limiting based on a defined max width or height.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.ExpandBackwards
member.summary: The "normal" direction of expansion when the defined row or column limit is met is right (for row-limited) and down (for column-limited), this inverts that so the container expands in the opposite direction as elements are added.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.Columns
member.summary: The number of columns to organize the children into. Setting this puts this grid into LimitMode.LimitColumns and LimitType.Count - items will be added to fill up the entire row, up to the defined limit of columns, and then create a second row.
member.exception: Thrown if the value assigned is less than or equal to 0.
member.returns: specified limit if LimitMode.LimitColums, otherwise the number of columns being used for the current amount of children.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.Rows
member.summary: The number of rows to organize the children into. Setting this puts this grid into LimitMode.LimitRows and LimitType.Count - items will be added to fill up the entire column, up to the defined limit of rows, and then create a second column.
member.exception: Thrown if the value assigned is less than or equal to 0.
member.returns: specified limit if LimitMode.LimitRows, otherwise the number of rows being used for the current number of children.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.MaxGridWidth
member.summary:
The max width (in virtual pixels) the grid of elements can have. This dynamically determines the number of columns based on the size of the elements. Setting this puts this grid into LimitMode.LimitColumns and LimitType.Size. Items will be added to fill up the entire row, up to the defined width, and then create a second row.
In the presence of unevenly-sized children, rows will still have the same amount elements - the items are laid out in a grid pattern such that they are all aligned, the height and width of each "cell" being determined by the greatest min height and min width among the elements. In the presence of expanding elements, their pre-expanded size will be used to determine the cell layout, then the elements expand within the defined Control.Size
member.exception: Thrown if the value assigned is less than or equal to 0.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.MaxGridHeight
member.summary:
The max height (in virtual pixels) the grid of elements can have. This dynamically determines the number of rows based on the size of the elements. Setting this puts this grid into LimitMode.LimitRows and LimitType.Size - items will be added to fill up the entire column, up to the defined height, and then create a second column.
In the presence of unevenly-sized children, columns will still have the same amount elements - the items are laid out in a grid pattern such that they are all aligned, the height and width of each "cell" being determined by the greatest min height and min width among the elements. In the presence of expanding elements, their pre-expanded size will be used to determine the layout, then the elements expand within the defined Control.Size
member.exception: Thrown if the value assigned is less than or equal to 0.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.CalculateLimitedCount
member.summary: If columns (or width) are being limited, calculates how many columns there should be.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.GridContainer.CellSize
member.summary: Calculates the size of a "cell" in physical pixels, for use in LimitType.Size mode. This is based on the maximum minheight / minwidth of each element.

member.name: F:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LimitType.Size
member.summary: Defined max width or height, inside of which the number of rows or columns will be fit.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LayoutContainer.SetAnchorPreset(Robust.Client.UserInterface.Control,Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LayoutContainer.LayoutPreset,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Changes all the anchors of a node at once to common presets. The result is that the anchors are laid out to be suitable for a preset.
member.param: The preset to apply to the anchors.

If this is true, the control margin values themselves will not be changed, and the control position and size will change according to the new anchor parameters. If false, the control margins will adjust so that the control position and size remains the same relative to its parent.
member.exception: Thrown if isn't a valid preset value.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LayoutContainer.SetMarginsPreset(Robust.Client.UserInterface.Control,Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LayoutContainer.LayoutPreset,Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LayoutContainer.LayoutPresetMode,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Changes all the margins of a control at once to common presets. The result is that the control is laid out as specified by the preset.
Note that the current size and minimum size of the control affects how each of the margins will be set, so if your control needs to shrink beyond its current size / min size, you should either not call this method or only call it when your control has a size of (0, 0). Otherwise your control's size will never be able to go below the size implied by the margins set in this method.
member.param: Some extra margin to add depending on the preset chosen.

member.name: T:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LayoutContainer.GrowDirection
member.summary: Controls how the control should move when its wanted size (controlled by anchors/margins) is smaller than its minimum size.

member.name: F:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.LayoutContainer.GrowDirection.End
member.summary: The control will expand to the bottom right to reach its minimum size.

member.summary: The control will expand to the top left to reach its minimum size.

member.summary: The control will expand on all axes equally to reach its minimum size.

member.summary: The control will not be allowed to grow on this axis.

member.name: T:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit
member.summary: A multi-line text editing control.

remarks.para: This control uses a to performantly manipulate editable text.

Text selection and cursor positions are tracked with two values: a "selection start" and a "cursor position". When you do not have a selection (i.e. just a lone cursor) these values are at the same position. If you have an active selection, the cursor position is the part of the selection you can move around (via mouse or shift+left/right), while the start is the part that stays in place always.
Positions inside this control are all in chars. Cursor positions and such should never be inside a surrogate pair, however.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit.CursorPosition
member.summary: The current position of the cursor in the text rope.
member.remarks: See the class remarks for how text selection works in this control.
member.exception: Thrown if the given position would put the cursor inside a surrogate pair.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit.SelectionStart
member.summary: The start position of the selection in the text rope.
member.remarks: See the class remarks for how text selection works in this control.
member.exception: Thrown if the given position would put the cursor inside a surrogate pair.

member.summary: The text rope that can be viewed and edited.

member.summary: True to allow editing by the user. False to make it read-only.

member.summary: The lower (in string index terms) end of the active text selection.
member.remarks: Confusingly, because text is read top-to-bottom, "lower" is actually higher up on your monitor.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit.SelectionUpper
member.summary: The upper (in string index terms) end of the active text selection.
member.remarks: Confusingly, because text is read top-to-bottom, "upper" is actually lower down on your monitor.

member.name: P:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit.Placeholder
member.summary: A placeholder text to be displayed when no actual text is entered.

remarks.para: This isn't editable by the user, but to make the internals simpler, it is still exposed as a rope.

When set to null, the placeholder style pseudo-class will not be applied when the actual text content is empty. If set to an empty text rope this does happen, but obviously no text is displayed either way.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit.CalcCursorMove(Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit.MoveType,System.Boolean,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Calculate the position the cursor should move to with a certain move.
member.remarks: This method is not pure: while it does not modify the actual cursor position yet, only calculating the next position, it still calls CacheHorizontalCursorPos manually.
member.param: The type of move the cursor is doing.
Whether a selection is being expanded.
Whether the cached horizontal cursor position must be kept instead of being invalidates.
member.returns: The new position of the cursor in the text.

member.name: T:Robust.Client.UserInterface.Controls.TextEdit.LineBreakBias
member.summary: Specifies which line the cursor is positioned at when on a word-wrapping break.

remarks.para: When words get pushed to a new line due to word-wrapping, a line break is tracked. For various reasons, people want to be able to place their cursor on both the end of the "top" line, as well as the start of the "bottom" line. These are however the same position in the source text, going by raw string indices at least. To allow the code to differentiate between these two positions, this bias value is tracked in all cursor positions.
This is only for word-wrapping line breaks however. For explicit line breaks created with a newline character, the cursor bias should always be "top" so that everything works correctly.

member.name: T:Robust.Client.UserInterface.XAML.Proxy.IXamlProxyManager
member.summary: This service provides a proxy for Populate, which is the generated function that initializes the UI objects of a Xaml widget.
member.remarks:
The proxy can always return false: in that case, a Xaml widget will self-populate as usual. This is the behavior on Release builds.
However, it can also call into an externally-provided implementation of the Xaml widget.
No source of externally-provided implementations actually exists, by default -- you will need to call SetImplementation with a blob of xaml source code to provide one. is an example of a service that calls into that functionality.

member.remarks: If the is not a stub, then it will spy on the assembly list (from ) and find entries on the loaded types.

member.name: M:Robust.Client.UserInterface.XAML.Proxy.IXamlProxyManager.CanSetImplementation(System.String)
member.summary: Return true if at least one in the current project expects its XAML to come from a file with the given name.
member.remarks:
This method supports code that is trying to figure out what name the build process would have assigned to a resource file. A caller can try a few candidate names and use its "yes" to continue.
This method is very fast, so it's OK to hammer it!
Also, on a non-tools build, this always returns false.
member.param: the filename
member.returns: true if expected

member.summary:
Replace the implementation of with , compiling it if needed.
All types based on will be recompiled.
member.remarks:
This may fail and the caller won't be notified. (There will usually be logs.)
On a non-tools build, this fails silently.
member.param: the name of the file
the new content of the file

Implementors of this delegate should inform the users of errors in their own way.

This type is inert and is generated for release artifacts too, not just debug artifacts. Released content should support hot reloading if loaded in a debug client, but this is untested.

member.name: F:Robust.Client.Utility.DiscordRichPresence.NativeLogger._successfullyConnected
member.summary: This library keeps trying to connect all the time and spams the client with error messages. To mitigate this annoyance, this variable keeps track of whether a connection was established (or whether it's the first time it's being attempted) so that we can print the error only when it's useful.
